conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As I'm looking to sell my resources and the production cost was 40 ZUP, I want to start with a proposal that gives me a profit margin. I will propose a higher amount initially to leave room for negotiation. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I'm offering one unit of X which cost me 40 ZUP to produce. Considering the quality and value of X, I propose a selling price of 50 ZUP. This is a starting point for our negotiation, so let me know what you think. </message>

<other player message> 
I understand the value you've placed on X and your cost of production. I'm interested in a fair deal that is beneficial for both of us. Considering that, I'd like to counter-propose with an offer of 42 ZUP for one unit of X. This ensures you make a profit while keeping the price within a range that I'm comfortable with.
 </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 42 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 2 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has offered 42 ZUP which covers my costs and offers a small profit. However, I believe the value of X justifies a higher price. I should aim to meet in the middle between my initial asking price and the counteroffer to maintain a negotiation space and achieve a better profit. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 46 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your counteroffer. I appreciate your understanding of the situation. I believe that X's value is quite significant, so I propose we meet halfway between our two figures. How about we settle on 46 ZUP for one unit of X? This price should reflect the fair value for both of us. </message>

<other player message> 
Meeting halfway is a good approach, and I'm glad we're moving towards a mutually agreeable price. To fine-tune our agreement, I propose 44 ZUP for one unit of X. This is slightly above the middle ground of our initial proposals and still offers you a fair profit. I believe this price fairly represents the value of X and aligns with my budget.
 </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 44 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 3 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE's new offer of 44 ZUP is considerate and closer to my last proposal. It's only 2 ZUP away from my last offer and provides a reasonable profit. It might be beneficial to secure a deal now rather than risk losing the sale over a small difference, especially since this is a fair price. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Your proposal of 44 ZUP for one unit of X is acceptable to me. It provides a fair profit margin for the quality of the resource I'm offering. Let's finalize this deal at 44 ZUP. </message>
